This facility is a municipal wastewater relcamation facility designed to utilize chlorine as a chemical disinfecting agent for the plant's effluent.  It utilizes approximately 15 lbs. of gaseous chlorine per day.  Chlorine is stored in 150 lb. cylinders as liquified chlorine under pressure.  The storage facility is designed to contain chlorine leaks by creating anegative draft through a totally enclosed room and scrubbing the vented gas through a caustic soda air scrubber.  The scrubber is designed to reduce chlorine concentration to less than 1 ppm.  In the event of the failure of the automatic containment system, manual backup is provided or facility staff are trained to contain leaks and minimize any release.  A copy of the Emergency Response Plan is attached as a separate ASCII file.
                         COUNTY OF MAUI
                      WASTEWATER DIVISION
       CHLORINE RELEASE PREVENTION & CONTAINMENT PROGRAM

I.   Purpose

     The purpose of this program is to provide an outline of safe working  
          practices and leak response procedures in order to protect both division
staff          personnel and the public from the potentially harmful exposure and affects
of        chlorine gas used at County of Maui Wastewater Reclamation Facilities.

II.  Policy

     It is the policy of the Wastewater Reclamation Division (WRF) to train     
          employees to work with chlorine safely and to respond promptly and
safely to           releases of chlorine gas from WRFs in order to protect the health
and welfare of the  staff and the community.

III. Responsibility

     A.   It is the responsibility of all division employees to comply with this     
          policy and to follow all safety procedures and leak response     
               procedures as outlined in this program.

     B.   Management and Supervisory personnel are responsible for the     
          enforcement of this policy.

IV.  Scope

     This Policy applies to all Division Employ

ees.

V.   Right to Know

     It is the responsibility of Supervisory personnel to inform staff of the   
          potential hazards of chlorine gas and what safety measures should be
taken if a     chlorine alarm is activated and/or should a leak occur.

     It is also the responsibility of Supervisory personnel to inform civilian  
          personnel (sales people, contractors, repair persons, DOSH Inspectors,
etc.) of the   potential hazards of chlorine gas and what to do if a chlorine alarm is
activated.     
VI.  Training

     A.   WRF staff who are directly employed at a Wastewater Facility where 
               chlorine gas is used shall receive training on the following topics:

          1.   Hazardous Communication Program
          2.   Safety Equipment
          3.   Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)
          4.   Respiratory Protection
          5.   Emergency Repair Kit A or B
          6.   Policy and Procedure Manual for Chlorine Release Prevention & 
               Containment

     B.   The Wastewater Operations Training Officer shall insure that quarterly 
               training is accomplished and documented for each WRF on the
topics              identified in Section VI-A.

     C.   The Wastewater Operations Training Officer shall conduct         
          unannounced in-plant drills for response to Level I, II, or III Alarm/Leak 
               conditions.  Drills shall also be conducted in conjunction with the
Maui                Fire Department with prior notification.  All drills will be documented
and       evaluation results kept on file.

VII. Safety Equipment

     A.   It shall be Wastewater Reclamation Division Management's         
          responsibility to assure that all necessary safety equipment is  
               available to WRFs and personnel for the safe handling of chlorine
and            safe response to chlorine releases.

     B.   It shall be the responsibility of WRF Supervisory personnel to properly

store, maintain, repair or replace all safety equipment assigned to 
               their Facility.

     C.   It shall be the responsibility of WRF Supervisory personnel and the 
               Wastewater Operations Training Officer to assure that staff are 
                    properly trained on the operation and maintenance of all
safety                   equipment.

VIII.     Record keeping

     A.   It shall be WRF Supervisory personnel responsibility to investigate all 
               chlorine alarm/leak incidents.  They shall submit a written report to 
               the Wastewater Operations Program Superintendent within 24
hours               of any chlorine alarm/leak incident.  The report shall include
the cause                of the incident, amount of any chlorine released, response to
the            incident, and an evaluation and any proposed corrective action for 
          improved future responses.    

     B.   The Wastewater Operations Training Officer shall maintain records of 
               staff training and qualified staff to work with and respond to chlorine
               incidents.

     A.   Chlorine Gas monitor located within the Chlorine Facility.  The  
          monitor will send a signal to the SCADA system to alert Plant    
               personnel and the Chlorine scrubber will be activated.

     B.   Plant personnel, while performing any kind of work in the Chlorine 
               Facility (loading or unloading cylinders, or moving cylinders).

     In either case, all Chlorine Alarms will be taken seriously and responses 
     shall be in a safe and proper manner.

II.  On-site personnel:
     
     Once a Chlorine Alarm/Leak condition has been activated, all on site Plant and 
     Civilian personnel shall be notified.  All personnel shall locate and

observe wind direction indicators (windsocks) and evacuate to a location   
     upwind of the Chlorine Facility.  All off-site personnel shall be notified by radio or 
     cellular phone of the incident.

III. Off-site personnel:

          response facility rendezvous site and standby for further instructions.

               on the scene at the safety zone, or

     D.   The Fire Department will make contact by telephone or by radio on

               chlorine facility, or at the rendezvous location, until the alarm
condition                has cleared and/or Responsible person has instructed
otherwise.

III. ENTRY TEAM

          operator, and Fire

Department Rescue (rescue/backup) person.

          Fire Department Rescue.
 
          1.   The Entry Operator shall close the cylinder valve(s) and check for 
               leaks.

          2.   The Standby Operator shall standby at the chlorine facility door 
                    with the Entry Operator in sight and shall provide assistance
or                  rescue to the Entry Operator.

          3.   Fire Department Rescue will provide rescue/backup to the Entry 
               Team.

          4.   The Entry Team will not be allowed to spend more than 30 minutes
               in the chlorine leak area.  The second (Standby) Entry Team may 
               be called in to relieve the first Entry Team if deemed necessary by 
               the IC.
  
     After rendezvous at the WRF safety zone or Rescue command center with the 
     IC, donning of the required PPE, and provided with rescue backup person in the 
     safety zone, the Entry Team will do the following upon reaching the chlorine 
     facility:

          1.   Observe the condition inside the chlorine cylinder room.  Look for 
               noticeable leaks.
     
          2.   Close the chlorine cylinder valve(s).

          3.   Check for leaks on the front, back, and sides of all cylinders (on-
               line, connected, and full standby cylinders). 
               a.   If a leak is found,  report findings to the command center for 
                    further instructions.  Identify the leak as either a minor or 
                    major, and either a gas or liquid leak. 

               b.   If no cylinder leaks are found after closing the valves, 
                         evacuate the area and return to command center for 
                         decontamination and debriefing.

                    iv.  Once the leak is secured, evacuate the area and

I.   Fire Department

     If the Fire Department evaluates the alarm to be a Level I situation, (verified by 
     having    less 3 ppm chlorine emitting downwind of WRF grounds), the
following will take place,    the Fire Department will:

     A.   Notify Central Dispatch for Police to standby.

     B.   Establish radio contact on Public Works channel or cellular phone contact 
          with WRF Standby Supervisor and Standby Operator and inform them of 
          the situation.

     C.   Provide standby/rescue for WRF Entry Team.

II.  Police Department

     The Police Department will standby for further notification from the Fire  
     Department if roadblocks are needed.  The Police Department will not approach 
     the WRF grounds upon receiving an alarm at Central Dispatch.

          1.   Standby Operators will meet at the rendezvous location.

                      GENERAL REQUIREMENTS

     Every Wastewater Reclamation Facility having a Chlorine Facility has different 
     environmental conditions, different chlorine facility location within Plant grounds, 
     and different access locations to Plant and chlorine facility, therefore, each
require   different Staging and Rendezvous Protocol for implementing the required
Action    Plan and Response Plan.

     Although each WRF requires different Staging and Rendezvous Protocol for 
          implementing theparticularlay Action Plan and Response Plan, there are 
          General Requirements common to all WRFs that need to be maintained
and  adhered to.

I.   RESPONSIBLE PERSON (INCIDENT COMMANDER)

     Once a chlorine alarm/leak condition has been activated, each WRF must 
          establish a Responsible Person or "competent person" to be in charge of
the       incident

.  The Responsible Person is responsible for Plant staff and public
safety.   The responsible person shall have thorough knowledge of their particular 
          chlorine facility and system, and be capable of implementing and adhering
to the    Division's Policy and Procedures for chlorine alarm/leak conditions for
Level I, II, and    III.  The Responsible Person shall be:

     A.   During the normal working hours (0700-1530)-WRF Supervisor or    
          Working Foreman (or TA)

     B.   After normal working hours (1530-0700)-WRF Supervisor (or TA)

     Responsible person shall monitor the Entry Team time and progress and not
make      entry into the chlorine facility.  They shall assume Incident Commander
upon      arrival at the command center.

II.  STAFF TRAINING

     All WRF staff shall be trained and knowledgeable of any and all Standard 
          Operating Procedures related to "CHLORINE USE" at the WRF they are 
          employed at.

III. ENTRY TEAM

     All WRFs shall have at minimum four (4) staff members trained and able to be 
     part of an entry team for responding to Level I, II, and/or III Hazardous Chlorine 
     Conditions.  The Entry Team shall be made up of an Entry person and a      
     Standby/Rescue person.  Each member shall be trained and capable of being 
     either.   Each Entry Team member shall be thoroughly trained and be
capable in the           knowledge and/or use of the following:

     A.   Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)

     B.   Tools & Equipment

     C.   Emergency B Repair Kit

     D.   Policies and Procedures for Action and Response Plans for Level I, II, or 
          III Hazardous Chlorine Conditions.

IV.  PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT (PPE)

     All WRFs shall have and be required to properly store and maintain any     
     Personal Protective Equipment necessary for responding to a Level I, II, or III 
          Hazardous Chlorine Condition.  PPE shall be strategically located to

accommodate the WRF's individual staging requirements.  PPE
requirements   are,      but not limited to the following:

     A.   Four (4) to six (6) positive pressure SCBAs with four (4) spare air   
          cylinders.

     B.   Minimum of four (4) Level A and/or B Chlorine Protection Suits (Chemral 
          Suits).
     
     C.   Six (6) to eight (8) pairs of chlorine resistant rubber gloves

     D.   Four (4) to six (6) pair of steel toed rubber boots.

     E.   Four (4) explosion proof lantern type flashlights with spare batteries.

     F.   Four (4) designated hard hats.

V.   TOOLS & EQUIPMENT

     All WRFs shall have response designated:

     A.   Ammonia vapor bottle(s).

     B.   Two (2) spare chlorine cylinder valve wrenches.

     C.   At minimum, one (1) Emergency B Repair Kit.  The Emergency Kit   
          shall be kept and properly maintained at the Chlorine Facility cylinder 
               room, and shall be well marked for easy identification and location.


VI.  WIND DIRECTION INDICATORS

     All WRFs shall have and maintain, easily visible wind direction indicators      
     strategically located throughout their WRF.  The wind direction indicator shall be 
     a wind sock and shall be fluorescent in color.

VII. CHLORINE GAS ALARM

     All WRFs shall have a Chlorine Gas Alarm System.  The chlorine alarm system 
     shall be:
     
     A.   Properly maintained, calibrated, and operational 24 hours a day, with,

          1.   A chlorine sensor located in the chlorine cylinder room, use, and 
               storage area.

     B.   The alarm system shall have:

          1.   A visible alarm indicator located in the chlorine facility.

          2.   Have audible alarm indicator(s) and shall be audible within the 
                    WRF grounds.  All staff members shall have a SCADA
pager to be              able to detect an alarm from the chlorine facility.
 
          3.   The chlorine alarm shall also be connected to Central

Dispatch 
                    and/or the Fire Department.  During normal working hours
(0700-              1530) the alarm will be disabled from Central Dispatch and 
                    enabled after work (1530-0700).
     
VIII.     COMMUNICATION EQUIPMENT

     All WRFs shall have and maintain communication devices.  Communication 
          devices shall be radio(s) channel 1 or 2, telephone and/or cellular
telephones.    Entry Teams may have separate communication devices which
shall be properly   maintained and operational at all times.

IX.  SAFETY ZONE, STAGING, & RENDEZVOUS 

     All WRFs shall establish (specific to their WRF) Safety Zones, Staging areas, 
     and Rendezvous locations for Level I, II, or III Response Conditions.

     A.   Safety Zone(s):     Shall be a safe zone or location (upwind of chlorine 
          facility) for WRF personnel to evacuate to in the event of a chlorine 
               alarm/leak.  Based on environmental and wind conditions, there
may be         several safety zones.

      B.  Staging & Rendezvous:    Shall be areas and/or locations where PPE 
          and Tools are stored, and shall be where the Entry Team will rendezvous,
          standby, and either pickup and/or don PPE before responding to a      
          chlorine alarm/leak condition.

     C.   Confirm Cylinder is empty and Isolate Cylinder

          1.   Record cylinder weight and verify 2000lbs. +or- has been used.

          2.   Verify with cylinder connected that no gas is flowing through the 
               chlorinator sight glass (dosage ball is not registering).

     D.   Isolate Valves

          1.   With the empty cylinder still under vacuum, isolate cylinder (close
               valve), and any other valves leading to a common header or to the 
               chlorinator.



     E.   Isolate and Disconnect cylinder

          With cylinder and other valves securely closed:

          1.   Disconnect yoke and whip assembly, and/or vacuum regulating 
                    check unit assembly, from the cylinder.

          2.   Discard the used lead washer.

          3.   Replace cylinder valve cap.

          4.   Replace cylinder valve hood.

     F.   Removal of Empty Cylinder and Placement of Full Cylinder

          Using the overhead hoist:

          1.   Position the hoist directly over the center of the cylinder.

          2.   Place and secure the cylinder clamp on the cylinder and hoist up.

          3.   Place cylinder in empty cylinder storage and mark cylinder with 
                    EMPTY sign.

          4.   Place FULL cylinder on hookup scale, positioning the gas valve at 
               the 12 o' clock position.  Carefully lower the full cylinder onto the 
               scale to avoid damage to the scale.
          
          5.

Record the total weight of the full cylinder.  Record the tare weight 
               of the cylinder.
                          
     G.   Connect Full Cylinder

          1.   Remove the cylinder valve hood.

          2.   Position the cylinder gas valve at the 12 o'clock position.

          3.   Check and verify that the gas valve is closed.

          4.   Remove gas valve cap.   Check for chlorine with ammonia while 
               removing the cap (use ammonia vapors only, never get ammonia 
               liquid on valve assemblies).
                                                                   
          5.   Place new lead washer on yoke and whip assembly, or vacuum 
                    regulator check unit assembly.  Secure either of the above 
                    assemblies to cylinder gas valve using cylinder valve wrench
                    (never use a wrench other than the chlorine wrench).




     H.   Place Cylinder on Line

          1.   Using the valve wrench, crack open the cylinder gas valve and 
                    close.  Check for gas leaks.  If a leak is detected, tighten
assembly            to the cylinder gas valve and/or check lead washer for
proper fit                    and tighten.  If no leak is detected, proceed with the
next step.

          2.   Re-open (3/4 - 1 turn) cylinder gas valve.  Check for leaks.

          3.   Open remaining gas line valves leading to the common header or 
               automatic valve assembly or to the chlorinator assembly.  Open 
                    one valve at a time, checking for leaks with each valve.  If a
leak is             detected, close the cylinder valve and refer to leak detection 
                    procedures.  If no leak is detected, proceed until gas line is
fully               charged and ready for use.

          4.   Label cylinder appropriately as either FULL STANDBY or FULL 
               IN USE.

     I.   Documentation

          Complete the appropriate paperwork

on chlorine usage log-date, time, 
               Operators, cylinder serial numbers, cylinder tare weight, cylinder
scale               weight, etc.

     J.   Communication

          Inform the Plant Supervisor and/or Working Foreman and the Plant staff 
          that the cylinder change is complete and that all is clear.

     K.   Cleanup

          Cleanup and return all PPEs and tools to the appropriate storage areas.  
          Verify that they are ready for use.

                    CHLORINE LEAK PROCEDURE
                                

I.   LEVEL I-NORMAL WORKING HOURS

     A.   Chlorine alarm sounds
          1.   Check wind direction
               a.   Proceed upwind
               b.   Never cross downwind of leak area

     B.   DRC Operator selects lead man & command post
          1.   Lead man to retrieve air packs
               a.   Air pack #1 is located in the store room
               b.   Air pack #2 is located in the store room
               c.   Air pack #3 is located at the pump station

          2.   Establish command post:
               a.   During normal tradewinds:
                    (1)  At the Office Trailer
               b.   During Kona Winds
                    (1)  At the Pump Station
          
          3.   Establish "buddy" system
               a.   Deter

mine the first man in:
                    (1)       Suits up
                         (a)  Coveralls
                         (b)  Air pack
               b.   Determine back up man
                    (1)       Suits up
                         (a)  Coveralls
                         (b)  Air pack

     C.   Investigate/Secure the leak

          1.   Establish a time limit for the first man in the room
               a.   Check present time
               b.   Determine when the backup man will come in 

          2.   First man in:
               a.   Start time for the backup man
               b.   Proceed to the Chlorine area
               c.   Be aware of signs of chlorine
                    (1)  Chlorine odor
                    (2)  Burning sensation
                    (3)  Yellow/green/blue floating gas near the ground
               d.   Observe the chlorine area for chlorine discharge
               e.   Determine the location of the leak
                    (1)  Not the main cylinder
                         (a)  Secure (close) the main cylinder valve
                         (b)  Return to the command post
                         (c)  Wait for the area to clear of chlorine
                              i.   Repair the leak
                              ii.  Test the repair
                              iii.      Return system to normal operation

                    (2)  The Main cylinder
                         (a)  Return to the command post
                         (b)  Notify 911
                         (c)  Go to Level III procedure

**Note: If the first man does not return to the command post within the    
established time period, proceed with Level III while the backup man retrieves the
first man in.

II.  LEVEL II-AFTER NORMAL WORKING HOURS

     A.   Proceed to the Plant and check for Chlorine alarm

          1.   Chlorine alarm activated
               a.   Do not enter the grounds
               b.   Determine the wind direction/upw

ind site
               c.   Call for assistance per call out list
                    (1)  Determine meeting site
                         (a)  Upwind site from Level I
                         (b)  Call Plant Supervisor and inform of situation
                    (2)  Notify 911 of possible problem
                         (a)  Request Fire Department assistance
                         (b)  Retrieve off-site air pack
                         (c)  Inform them of upwind site
                    (3)  Wait of assistance at the upwind site
               d.   Assistance arrives
                    (1)  Do not proceed until Fire Department arrives
                    (2)  Lead man suits up
                         (a)  Coveralls
                         (b)  Air pack
                    (3)  Back up man suits up
                         (a)  Uses Plant gear if available
                         (b)  Uses Fire Department gear
               e.   Proceed per Level I-B-3 procedure

          2.   Chlorine alarm not activated
               a.   Insure Chlorine odor is not present
               b.   Determine reason of call out
               c.   Proceed as usual

III.      LEVEL III-MAJOR LEAK OF CHLORINE CYLINDER

     A.   Evacuate the area
          1.   Retrieve the air packs, if possible 
          2.   Insure all personnel are removed from the grounds
          
     B.   Notify 911 of the situation
          1.   Determine if civilian evacuation is required
               a.   If yes, request Police Department assistance
               b.   If unknown, request Police Department assistance

     C.   Notify all parties on Level III call out
          1.   Notify the Chlorine vendor of the situation
               a.   All information regarding the cylinder involved
                    (1)  Size of the cylinder
                    (2)  Serial numbers, if any

          2.   Determine location of the repair kit
               a.   Retrieve, if possible

b.   Have the vendor bring an extra repair kit

     D.   Wait until all assistance needed has arrived before proceeding
          1.   Assist Chlorine vendor where possible
          2.   Account for all Plant personnel involved
               a.   Determine if medical help is required
               b.   Administer oxygen for any personnel affected
                    (1)  Contact hospital if necessary
                    (2)  Request ambulance if necessary
